sub_topic: Calculating the molar mass of inorganic compounds
message_1: What is the molar mass of barium sulfate, BaSO4?
message_2:
To find the molar mass of barium sulfate (BaSO4), we need to add the molar masses of each element in the compound.

Barium (Ba) has a molar mass of 137.33 g/mol.
Sulfur (S) has a molar mass of 32.07 g/mol.
Oxygen (O) has a molar mass of 16.00 g/mol.

The formula for barium sulfate is BaSO4, which means it has one barium atom, one sulfur atom, and four oxygen atoms.

So, the molar mass of barium sulfate is:

(1 × 137.33 g/mol) + (1 × 32.07 g/mol) + (4 × 16.00 g/mol) = 137.33 + 32.07 + 64.00 = 233.40 g/mol

The molar mass of barium sulfate (BaSO4) is 233.40 g/mol.
